info: Rosenwald Hall was built to house the Geology and Geography departments, so the outside is covered with imagery of people and objects related to those pursuits. Julius Rosenwald, president of Sears, Roebuck, granted the University $250,000 to construct the building. After the aforementioned departments, Rosenwald housed the business school from 1972 until it moved to its current location.

image.image_caption: This is a placeholder image from the '80s. Stuff was weird then. Weird.
This was the camera Jackson used to own. If you have seen it, please let him know. Remember: See something? Say something.
This was the camera Jackson used to own. If you have seen it, please let him know. Remember: See something? Say something.

info: This building used to display artifacts from the University’s natural history program (which is why it’s called Walker Museum). Most  were sent to the Field Museum in the 1920s, but some fossils remained until the 1980s, when the Booth School of Business expanded into the Museum from its home in Rosenwald. Currently, the Financial Aid Office and the offices of the Humanities Division call Walker home.

info: Lots of cool stuff happening here. You can ocassionsally find squirrels here.

Harper Memorial Library, which was named for the University’s first president, William Rainey Harper, was the University’s main library until the Regenstein library opened in 1970. The gorgeous, historic reading room is open 24 hours a day, six days a week. Over the last few decades, Harper has gradually been converted to house administrative units of the college including the College Programming Office, Study Abroad, advising, and the offices of both the Dean of the College and the Dean of Students in the College. The reading room and computer lab were recently renovated to create a space for group work and better accommodate new  technology.

The Joseph Bond Chapel is connected to Swift Hall, home of the Divinity School, by a peaceful stone cloister. The chapel contains a bronze plaque designed by the famous sculptor Lorado Taft that was originally donated by Mrs. Joseph Bond in memory of her husband, who served as a trustee for the Baptist Theological Union (predecessor of the Divinity School). The inscription, which Mrs. Bond composed, reads: “Erected in Memory of Joseph Bond for the Worship of God and the Service of Man, 1926.” A section of the wood paneling near the tablet has been carved to read “Peace I Leave With You.”

Since it’s construction in 1926, Swift Hall has housed the departments relating to theology and religion, including the University of Chicago Divinity School. Bond Chapel is used both for multi-denominational religious service and private events like weddings for University affiliated individuals. The basement of the building is the home of student favorite coffee shop “Grounds of Being” where the slogan is “Where God Drinks Coffee.”

More info: https://divinity.uchicago.edu/bond-chapel

Cobb is the oldest building on campus, and the first designed by architect Henry Ives Cobb (no relation to Silas Cobb, the building’s namesake). The building is one of the centers of undergraduate education; it’s almost impossible to graduate without taking a class here eventually.

Cobb Lecture Hall was the first University of Chicago building completed when the University first held classes on October 1, 1892. The building was modeled after the Gothic style featured prominently on the Oxford University campus in England, and it was the most expensive of the original sixteen buildings. It included a “general recitation” hall and a chapel in addition to classrooms and offices.

Cobb Lecture Hall faces inward toward the main quadrangle, leaving its street-side façade sparse. Its interior design is largely utilitarian, reflecting Cobb’s Chicago School influences, though inflections of Gothic revival are still apparent.

After the School of Social Service Administration was finished south of the Midway and its related offices moved, Cobb Lecture Hall became entirely dedicated to the humanities and social sciences. The Center for the Study of Languages, The Film Studies Center, the Language Center, and the Renaissance Society are all headquartered here.

Botany Pond is named for the nearby Botany building (even though the University no longer has a Botany department). Hitchcock house, one of the college houses, throws newly elected house presidents into the water in a tradition called “ponding.”
Another water feature here.

The Reynolds Club is the center of on-campus extra-curricular activities for students. Not only is the Office of the Reynolds Club of Student Activities located in the basement, but there are two theaters used for student productions, a student run coffee shop, and the office of WHPK, the University’s radio station.

Regenstein Library, referred to as “The Reg” by virtually everyone, was the largest building on campus when it was built in 1970. Originally it was intended only for graduate students at the University, but eventually undergrads were allowed access, and the Reg became the de facto locus of studying for all students. The Joe and Riva Mansueto Library, which opened in 2011, offers students a silent study space, and houses thousands of volumes in a massive filing system underground.

This dining commons serves as the default dining hall for most residence halls north of the Midway. Bartlett was originally built as a gymnasium for students, and there’s an empty swimming pool in the basement that’s strictly off limits.
People live in these ugly things.

The Field House used to be the primary location for athletics and fitness on campus (it was supplanted by the opening of Ratner Athletic Center) and still serves the University community with exercise equipment, racquetball courts, and general purpose areas for RSO use.

The Smart Museum of Art, which is free for the enjoyment of the entire community, has more than 12,000 objects on rotating display. The collection is based in the four artistic fields of European, Asian, Contemporary, and Modern art and Design.

The Court Theater, a professional theater company unaffiliated with the University of Chicago, was named “the most consistently excellent theater company in the country” by the Wall Street Journal. Students can receive steeply discounted tickets with a UChicago ID.

The Ratner Athletic Center opened in 2002. It was designed with an extensive load-bearing cable and mast system which makes the building resemble a large sailing ship. Facilities for varsity athletics are located here, and the glass cases in the front entranceway hold, among other things, Jay Berwanger’s Heisman Trophy, the first ever awarded.
